summary: This is a transcript of a July 12, 2021, DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview with a Federal Bureau of Prisons Lieutenant regarding the circumstances surrounding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) on August 10, 2019. The interview focuses on the lieutenant's role, staff assignments, protocols, and potential failures in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on August 9-10, 2019.

events.title: Cellmate Removed from MCC
events.description: An inmate (cellmate of Jeffrey Epstein) was removed from the Metropolitan Correctional Center via a 'WAB' (possibly 'Writ of Attachment Body') process. The interview probes notifications and subsequent actions regarding assigning Epstein a new cellmate.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell in the MCC Special Housing Unit (SHU).

events.title: DOJ OIG Interview
events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary interview with a BOP Lieutenant as part of its investigation into Epstein's death.

locations: Federal Correctional Institution (FCI) Danbury, Danbury, CT (interview location)
Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), New York, NY (location of Epstein's death)
keyFacts: The interview is part of an official DOJ OIG investigation into the death of Jeffrey Epstein and the surrounding circumstances at the MCC.
Epstein had attempted suicide on July 23, 2019, and was placed on suicide watch. The interview probes why he was removed from that watch and the instructions that he required a cellmate.

A key line of questioning involves the removal of Epstein's cellmate on August 9, 2019, and whether proper procedures were followed to assign him a new one, as well as the falsification of count and round logs.

The interviewer asks detailed questions about staff responsibilities, communications, camera functionality, an unauthorized phone call made by Epstein, and cell search policies, suggesting multiple potential protocol failures.

The document reveals the names of several BOP staff (Captain Darden, CO Michael Thomas, CO Tova Noel) who were on duty or involved in operations related to Epstein's housing around the time of his death.
